finalPattern.pattern_name: Framing practical, real-world claims as a myth-busting question in the title (‚ÄúDo/Does X actually work?‚Äù) on outlier topics, paired with a decisive hands-on test, materially increases CTR and expands reach beyond the core audience, yielding 3x+ TPS over the channel baseline.

evidence.title: Do tire balancing beads actually work?
evidence.excerpt: Outlier, practical automotive topic + ‚Äúactually work?‚Äù title + hands-on experiment; TPS far above channel norm.

data.statement: Framing a practical, widely-searched claim as a myth-busting question in the title ("Do/Does X actually work?") on an outlier, real-world topic‚Äîpaired with a clear hands-on experiment‚Äîsignificantly boosts CTR and reach beyond the channel‚Äôs core audience, driving 3x+ TPS.
data.reasoning: The title uses a proven curiosity gap pattern ("actually work?") that promises resolution to a common, contentious claim. Choosing an outlier, everyday topic (automotive tire beads) expands total addressable audience beyond the channel‚Äôs typical physics enthusiasts while still aligning with Steve‚Äôs explanatory brand. The format suggests a decisive, testable outcome (myth-busting) and invites non-subscribers who search for or encounter debates about tire balancing beads. The combination of novelty to the channel (topic outlier), broad utility, and a strong question-frame likely improves click-through and sharing, while the hands-on experiment sustains retention‚Äîtogether producing outsized TPS.
